description.p: Her fists a blur as they deflect an incoming hail of arrows, a half-elf springs over a barricade and throws herself into the massed ranks of hobgoblins on the other side. She whirls through them, each blow seeming to be more deadly than the last, until at last she stands alone.

A group of explorers has fought their way through the jungle to the abandoned temple, and has stopped outside to prepare to enter. As the others tend to minor wounds and sharpen their weapons, one of their number, a tattoo-covered human, begins to go through a series of graceful poses. One by one, the others begin to follow his lead, until, fortified and recentered, they all pass through the dark door before them.

The Land’s Defenders are finally facing the Dread Archmage. As they draws weapons and prepares magics, he cackles and releases a storm of fire towards the group. But a black-clad halfling leaps from the shadows into the very path of the flame, shielding their friends from the worst of the effects. The archmage recoils to see the small figure so nearby, and they swiftly close the remaining distance to pummel him with blows so quick and accurate as to confound his spellcasting.

Martial Artists have studied to be able to harness an energy known as ki that flows through all living bodies. Though very similar to Monks, Martial Artists have sacrificed some of the focus on stunning their enemies, and in return have gained a far greater flexibility to use their ki for a wide variety of techniques. They can choose to focus their physical and mental training not just on attacking and defensive moves, but also on expanding their senses, infiltration, or mobility.

Martial artists follow many different traditions. One of them might learn techniques honed by an oppressed people who learned to wield their very chains against the overlords who enslaved them; while another might have studied in a mountaintop monestary, taught by veterans of a horrible conflict who had turned to asceticism.

But each martial artist, whether they’re aesthete noble who insists on artistry in all things or a self-taught street brawler, pushes their body beyond its normal limits through study of a magical energy that most traditions call ki. Martial artists harness this power within themselves to create magical effects and exceed their bodies’ physical capabilities, and some of their special attacks can hinder the flow of ki in their opponents. Using this energy, martial artists channel uncanny speed and strength into their unarmed strikes. As they gain experience, their martial training and their mastery of ki gives them more power over their own bodies and those of their foes.

Still, each martial artist is unique. Like Monks, each select a monastic tradition, a Way which gives them extra abilities and features. But in addition, each one studies their choice of individual techniques available to all Ways. One martial artist might focus on techniques to guide and aid their allies; another might hone their defensive techniques to become almost untouchable in battle; while yet another might develop such an array of different attacks that their enemies never know what will come next.

With so many options to choose from, a martial artist is most effective when they have the wits to choose the right tool for each job. Though their attacks are physical rather than arcane, in some ways they have more in common with a Wizard than with a Barbarian. Like a Wizard with her spells, they must choose wisely which techniques to learn; then, in combat, choose which to use. This path of training and discipline is not for everyone, but its rewards can be great.
As an martial artist, you gain the following class features.

ul.li: Hit Dice: 1d10 per martial artist level
Hit Points at 1st Level: 10 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d10 (or 6) + your Constitution modifier per martial artist level after 1st
Armor: None
Weapons: Simple weapons, shortswords
Tools: Choose one set of artisan’s tools or one instrument
Saving Throws: Strength, Dexterity
Skills: Choose two from Acrobatics, Athletics, History, Insight, Religion, and Stealth

description.p: Your practice of martial arts gives you mastery of combat styles that use unarmed attacks and martial artist weapons, which are shortswords and any simple melee weapons that don’t have the two-handed or heavy property.
You gain the following benefits while you are unarmed or wielding only martial artist weapons and you aren’t wearing armor or wielding a shield.

ul.li: You can use Dexterity instead of Strength for the attack and damage rolls of your unarmed attacks and martial artist weapons.

You can roll a d4 in place of the normal damage of your unarmed attack or martial artist weapon. You can use a larger die as you gain martial artist levels, as shown in the Martial Arts column of the Martial Artist table.
You can use any feature which protects you or your allies despite lacking the right weapon(s), armor, or shield to do so. Examples: Defensive Duelist; Protection fighting style.
You can make one unarmed or one-handed martial artist weapon attack as a bonus action.

When you take the Dodge action, you get the usual benefit, but it lasts a bit longer. Until the end of your next turn, any attack roll made against you has disadvantage if you can see the attacker, and you make Dexterity saving throws with advantage. You lose this benefit if you are incapacitated or if your speed drops to 0.

sheet.description: Your unarmed strike does 1d{{martial arts:dice}}+{{martial arts:damage}} damage. You can use Strength or Dexterity for these attacks. When you use the Attack action with an unarmed strike or a monk weapon on your turn, you can make one unarmed strike as a bonus action. For example, if you take the Attack action and attack with a quarterstaff, you can also make an unarmed strike as a bonus action, assuming you haven’t already taken a bonus action this turn. You can use any feature which protects you or your allies despite lacking the right weapon(s), armor, or shield to do so. You lose this benefit if you are incapacitated or if your speed drops to 0.

description.p: In your study of martial and meditative arts, your dedicated practice has let you choose between certain special techniques to master.

At 1st level, you can choose one technique from the options detailed at the end of the class description. As you gain levels as a martial artist , you learn additional techniques, as shown in the Techniques Known column of the Martial Artist table.

Additionally, when you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the optional techniques you know and replace it with another technique. You can not replace a technique that is a prerequisite for another technique you know, and the replacement must have a level prerequisite lower than that of some technique you could learn.

If a technique has prerequisites, you must meet them to learn it. You can learn the technique at the same time that you meet its prerequisites. A level prerequisite refers to your level in this class. When a technique lets you cast a spell, your spellcasting ability is Wisdom.

Your speed increases by {{monk:unarmored movement}} feet while you are not wearing armor or wielding a shield. You gain the ability to move along vertical surfaces and across liquids on your turn without falling during the move.

description.p: Starting at 2nd level, your training allows you to harness the mystic energy of ki, and to use the basic ki techniques below. Your access to this energy is represented the maximum ki points in the Ki Points column of the Martial Artist table.
You can spend these points to fuel the basic ki techniques below, as well as many of the techniques you will choose.

When you spend a ki point, it is unavailable until you finish a short or long rest, at the end of which you draw all of your expended ki back into yourself. You must spend at least 30 minutes of the rest meditating to regain your ki points.
Some of your ki features, as well as certain martial arts techniques (below), require your target to make a saving throw to resist the feature’s effects. The DC is calculated as:
Ki save DC = 8 + proficiency bonus + Wisdom modifier
As a bonus action, you can spend 1 ki point to make two unarmed attacks.
As an action, you can regain up to your wisdom modifier in ki points. Once you do this, you cannot do so again until you finish a short or long rest.

As a bonus action, you can clear your mind and focus on your breathing. Once before the start of your next turn, when you would use a technique (including basic or novice ki techniques), you reduce the ki cost of that technique by 1 (to a minimum of 0).
As a bonus action, you can spend 1 ki point to take the Dodge action. As noted above, the benefits lasts until the end of your next turn.
As a bonus action, you can spend 1 ki point to take the Dash or Disengage action.
When you do, for the rest of this turn, your jump distance is doubled, and your melee attacks get +2 to attack and damage if you’ve moved since your last attack.

description.p: When you reach 3rd level, you commit yourself to a monastic (aka martial arts) tradition, chosen from the list of available traditions for the Monk class.

Your tradition grants you features at 3rd level and again at 6th, 10th, and 17th level. Note that 10th level is one level earlier than a Monk would gain the corresponding feature. Anywhere the rules for your tradition say "Monk", you can replace it with "Martial Artist".
There are a few new rules regarding traditions:

ul.li: Kensei monks can use strikes when they hit with a martial artist melee weapon.

Tradition features that add effects to unarmed strikes, such as Way of the Open Hand’s Open Hand Technique or Quivering Palm, count as strike techniques and thus cannot be combined with other strike techniques.

Any tradition feature which spends 2 or more ki to cast a spell counts as a technique for Focused Breathing. Once you have used focused breathing to cast a given spell twice, you cannot reduce that spell’s ki cost again until you finish a short or long rest.
See the end of this document for optional rules to simplify choosing techniques for each monastic tradition.

description.p: When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or increase two abilities by 1, or take a Feat from the Feat List. You can’t get an ability above 20 using an ASI.

If you then choose to use a strike technique that requires the target to make a saving throw, subtract the amount from the saving throw result. Otherwise, add the amount as extra damage.
Prerequisite: 17 Dexterity or 11th level

description.p: Starting at 11th level, basic/novice ki techniques all improve:

ul.li: When you use Flurry of Blows, you can make a total of three unarmed attacks. The third attack cannot be replaced or augmented using monastic tradition features.

When you use Step of the Wind, you get the benefits of both the Disengage and Dash actions. Likewise, when you use Critical Strike, you get both benefits: both subtracting from any saving throw and adding to damage.

When you use Patient Defense or Focused Breathing, you can use your reaction one extra time before the start of your next turn. This costs 1 ki unless your Monastic Tradition lets you use your reaction extra times. (You can never react more than once to the same triggering event.)

description.p: Beginning at 14th level, your mastery of ki grants you proficiency in all saving throws.

At 20th level, when you take a short rest, you can forego all the normal benefits of the rest to learn a technique of your choice. When you learn a new flexible technique in this manner, you forget any previous flexible technique you knew. Once you have used this feature, you can not do so again until you finish a long rest.
If you use this feature to learn a technique that requires 18th level as a prerequisite, you can not use this feature again for 1 year.
